Posts.Content: May 2, 2012 04:52PM Fergy wrote: YEAH Mommygg19, so happy for you!
Posts.Title: What was your BIRAD score prio to diagnosis? Mommygg19 hawaiik

Posts.Content: May 18, 2012 09:19AM Fergy wrote: Gayle, Glad that I could be of help.  Like some of the other ladies said most people get a benign result and then they don't post here any longer.  The ones that do post regularly are usually women with a cancer diagnosis.  I try to log in every now and then just so people that are waiting do hear from someone with B9 experience.  Although I have to admit I am not very vigilante about it either. When I was going through my testing process I was looking for people with B9 experiences.  There were a few that were going through the testing process at the same time I was and most of them got the cancer diagnosis.  I actually felt guilty when mine was B9, it seemed selfish of me in some way.  Not that anyone made me feel that way, it was all in my heart.  I will be hoping for a B9 result for you as well.  Sometimes the constant surveillance seems like a big disruption in our lives but it just means that if we ever do get cancer it will most likely be caught early. I read the post of women with DCIS that receive diagnosis, opt for BMX, get reconstruction, no chemo, no radiation and get on with their life and I think "Yep, that is why I go for my checkup regularly and do SBE".  If I have to get breast cancer I want it caught as early as possible. Good Luck and keep posting.  I have come a long way from being hysterical and worried to death 3 years ago to "yeah, whatever" today.  Also reading about so many survivors helps ease the fear too.  BC is no longer a death sentence for most people.  My cousins wife was diagnosed 6 months after my scare and she died 2 years after her diagnosis.  She had a very aggressive cancer, which is rare, and she had complications after her mastectomy that delayed her chemo treatments.  And still I don't get concerned because I know she was a rare case.
Posts.Title: biopsy monday gayle121 gayle121

Posts.Content: May 17, 2012 07:35PM Fergy wrote: Hello gayle121, I am 55 yrs old.  3 years ago I had a mammogram with a BIRAD 4C rating.  I was referred to a breast surgeon and rushed into a stereotactic biopsy within a week.  I had been told by the radiologist that I only had a 5% chance of benign results.  During the biopsy they extracted all of the microcalcifications and I was diagnosed with sclerosing adenosis, a benign breast abnormality.  So yes your symptoms can be a benign condition.  I was followed up with close servailance for a year and now have annual mammograms labeled high risk. I was told that sclerosing adenosis presents like cancer and cannot be diagnosed without biopsy.  So unfortunately, you will have to have the biopsy in order for them to know which it is. I am going for my annual physical next month and I have a new, very small, lump so I am going to ask for a diagnostic mammo and ultra sound.  If I get a BIRADS 4 again it will be tempting to just say it is probably sclerosing adenosis again but I don't think I would want to gamble and take the chance that it might be cancer. Most hospitals will let you pay in payments, interest free.  I am self employed and pay for my own insurance so I have a high deductible.  My hospital let me pay over a 12 month period.  I later found out if I had the biopsy done at a different facility and paid cash without involving the insurance it would have cost me less out of pocket.  Hope this helps.
Posts.Title: biopsy monday gayle121 gayle121

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2012 02:41PM Fergy wrote: Mommygg19 can you tell us what your results were from the lumpectomy and lymph node removal? 3 years ago I had a BIRADS 4C and the results were a benigned condition called sclerosing adenosis.  It causes clusters of calcifications the same as some cancers do.  Like the other ladies have said, everyone that gets a biopsy has either BIRADS 4 or 5 otherwise they would not be getting a biopsy.  80% of biopsies are benign.  I was fortunate in they took out all of the calcifications with the biopsy and I haven't had any new ones since.  Hope this helps.

Posts.Title: Wife has Hard Lump worriedhusband FilterLady

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2010 07:58AM Fergy wrote: I had a mammogram done in the spring of 2009 that was rated Birads 4C and suggested stereotactic biopsy.  My doctor called me in a panic and said I needed to see a breast surgeon right away because the radiologist told him that he was 95% sure it was a malignancy.  The breast surgeon squeezed me in when she found out it was Birads 4C and the biopsy was scheduled a week later.  My biopsy results came back showing Sclerosing Adenosis which mimicks cancer but is a B9 condition that only increases your risk of cancer.  I had a follow up mammogram six months later that showed everything was stable and now I am due for my annual mammogram, which I suspect will be normal again. BIRADS 4C is one step below a BIRADS 5 rating which is a known cancer or 98% sure of cancer.  It is not to be taken lightly.  However you NEVER know exactly what the problem is until you have a biopsy and get the pathology report back.  No matter what the radiologist says you still have an 80% chance of a benign result with your biopsy.  I drove myself crazy waiting for the results, my surgeon made me wait a full week for the results even though she had them 2 days after the biopsy.  URGH!  If I ever have to do that again I will assume a B9 outcome until I get the results.
Posts.Title: scared hopeful34 dlb823

Posts.Content: May 4, 2012 11:11AM Fergy wrote: momschki, Thank you for sharing that information.  I am guessing that it is viewed much like palm reading or tarrot cards by some in the medical community.  I think they are afraid that women will do thermography instead of mammograms and not be diagnosed early. Stangely, having the thermography done gave me a sense of comfort since I am so skeptical of mammorgram results.  I think doctors rely too much on them and they give a lot of false negatives and false positives as well. My cousins wife in the UK had her mammogram in June 2009, nothing showed up.  December 2009 she found a lump and was diagnosed with breast cancer, fought for 2 years and died December 2011.  When they went back to look at the June mammogram after her diagnosis they saw nothing.  So it makes me wonder why are we ONLY doing mammograms every year?
Posts.Title: No Touch Breast Scan momoschki twistedsteel

Posts.Content: May 5, 2012 10:33AM Fergy wrote: Thank you kayb for sharing that information. Interestingly, the technician that did my imaging is a breast cancer survivor as well.  She said that is what caused her to change careers and start doing the thermographic imaging.  She had a normal mammogram and an abnormal thermal imaging so she pushed for ultrasound and MRI and that is how her cancer was detected.  She had lumpectomy and chemo and gets her mammogram and thermal imagining done annually and stressed that the more data we have the better we can advocate for ourselves. I guess the thermal imaging will always be contraversial but as I said in an earlier post it gave me some comfort knowing that my symptoms could be due to excess estrogen in my breasts, mammogram, US and MRI cannot measure estrogen levels in the breast only thermography can.   Come July I will be there for my annual mammogram and will discuss with my doctor the excess estrogen in my breast since I am not on HRT and am post menopausal.
Posts.Title: No Touch Breast Scan momoschki twistedsteel

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2012 10:41AM Fergy wrote: momoschki, if you could post back what your BS has to say about it I would appreciate it.  Hopefully it is what your OB/GYN said it is. Also, I want to emphasize that the Thermal Imaging Center that I went to strongly emphasized that you should not use this imaging as a replacement for mammogram.  The literature that they gave me stated it and the technician mentioned it multiple times.
Posts.Title: No Touch Breast Scan momoschki twistedsteel

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2012 10:34AM Fergy wrote: OK, I am so glad that I stumbled across this thread.  I just had my very first thermal breast imaging done a couple of weeks ago. I have had 'busy breasts' for years, had a total of 5 biopsies over the years with the last one being a stereotactic biopsy in 2009 due to calcifications on mammogram.  I was diagnosed with sclerosing adenosis, a benign condition that increases your chances for some cancers.   I have been on an annual mammogram schedule for 2 years.  About 6 months ago I started having a pulling sensation in my right breast, along with increasing sharp pains like electrical shocks.  I have had the sharp pains before but never this annoying pulling sensation.  I have very lumpy, ropey breasts so it is difficult for me to find new lumps or ropes.  Consequently I am not very good about doing breast exams. I have my annual check up in June, will ask for a breast exam and get my script for the mammogram.  It was suggested by a member on this board that I get the Thermal Imaging done so I did.  It did not show any unusual vascular activity and I was given a TH-2 (low) risk rating.  My Hormonal Grade was 3 which is high and the report says "Some cancer does not produce suffiecient heat to be seen on thermography, recommend follow up thermography in 1 year"   The Hormonal grade said that it describes the level of estrogen activity in my breasts which may be associated with breast pain, breast lumps and/or increased risk.  Which I found to be odd because last year I had hormonal testing done and was told that my ovaries are no longer producing estrogen and my estrogen level was so low it was negligable.  So how do I have high estrogen levels in my breast? momoschki, I was just the opposite of you, I was relieved when I received the results but now I am unsure again.  Like you I never intended to use the thermography as a replacement for mammogram and fully intended to get my clinical exam and mammogram done this summer.  However, now that I have read this post I think I will ask for an ultrasound too.   I feel that there is something wrong but cannot detect if it is gutt feeling or fear.  In 2009 I really felt for sure that the biopsy was going to come back postitive and thought well if they missed something then it will show up again.  But I have not had any microcalcificaton since then so I am leaning toward less of instinct and more of fear.   Thanks for sharing this.  I had posted that I did Thermography on another site but didn't get any feedback.  My post was pretty much ignored.  I am guessing that most women don't approve of it.
Posts.Title: No Touch Breast Scan momoschki twistedsteel

Posts.Content: May 6, 2012 10:44AM - edited May 6, 2012 10:45AM by Fergy envirodoc,  I am sure that Thermography have helped SOME women to detect breast cancer that the mammogram and/or ultrasound did not detect.  HOWEVER, I have also read of documented cases where mammogram and/or ultrasound has detected cancer that Thermography did not.  Therefore I stand by my opinion that Thermography, Mammography and Ultra Sound are ALL good tools for detecting breast cancer.  Not just one or the other.  I would throw MRI in there too if it wasn't so cost prohibitive.  Yes, we do have freedom of choice as to whether we should have tests done or not.  I personally think getting thermal imagining without mammography is short changing yourself.  Even the literature from the Thermal Imaging lab states that some cancers do not show up on the scans.  Just like we have freedom to choose our treatments, we also have freedom to our opinions about them.
Posts.Title: No Touch Breast Scan momoschki twistedsteel

Posts.Content: May 4, 2012 10:35PM Fergy wrote: thenewme, I agree with what you say about the fear that women would use thermography as a replacement for mammogram.  It is completely painless and that would be the real draw. The imaging center that I had my thermographic imaging done at STRONGLY emphasized that it was not a replacement for mammography or any other tests.  All of their literature and the technician repeated it several times.  Personally I think annual mammogram and ultra sound should be the standard of care for all women.  MRI is expensive and I can see how the insurance companies would not want that done every year without cause.
Posts.Title: No Touch Breast Scan momoschki twistedsteel

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2009 12:47PM Fergy wrote: juliarose, I had a mammo done Sept 2008 with a BIRADS 3 and suggested a 6 mo follow up.  In March 2009 I had the follow up mammo and got a BIRADS 4C and they suggested a stereotactic biopsy which came back B9 with a precancerous condition.  The precancerous condition puts me at higher risk for cancer but does not mean that I will get cancer.  I go next week for my 6 mo follow up mammo and expect that it will be clear and I can go back to my annual mammograms. There are a lot of women on these discussion boards that had BIRADS 4 that got B9 results.  Never give up hope!  I know it is hard not to freak out because the medical personal freak out with a BIRADS 4 result but you still have an 80% chance of benign from the biopsy.  Only 20% of ALL biopsies are malignant. Fergy
Posts.Title: having excisional biopsy done monday MaggieTheArtist clariceak

Posts.Content: May 24, 2012 12:28AM - edited May 24, 2012 12:30AM by Fergy wilson33, I had Thermal Imaging done here in the states.  Arizona to be specific.  I would be interested to hear what you think.  I actually had it done the beginning of April, received the report on April 12th and just now got around to really looking at it.  Initially I felt it gave me comfort when I saw that I was givne a risk rate of 2 which is considered low for vascular activity.  However I noticed that it also said "Symmetrical vascular warming in the upper surfaces consistent with estrogen activity extending halfway to the nipple line.  Hormone Grade 2-3, medium to high, this grade describes the level of estrogen activity in your breasts, which may be associated with breast pain, breast lumps and/or increase risk." So I called today to ask more questions regarding the result and the technician said that the hormone grade means that I am estrogen dominent and that puts me at a higher risk for breast cancer.  He encouraged me to find a homeopathic doctor that would prescribe progesterone to balance it out.  He also told me if I look at the black and white photos I could see vascular activity in my right breast that I don't have in my left breast and that could be a sign of something in the early stages of development.  WHAT???  So now I am a little confused. At any rate, I am going to my PCP tomorrow for my annual physical and will get my annual mammogram and ultra sound next week.  I will discuss the estrogen dominance issue with him as well.  By the way it was my right breast that I had a biopsy done on 3 years ago for microcalcifications and was diagnosed with sclerosing adenosis.  It is also the breast that I have found a new pea size lump in that has not grown since I discovered it about 2 months ago. Please share with me what your report says and how it aligns with the mammogram and/or ultra sounds you have had.
Posts.Title: Itchy left nipple wilson33 Gingerbits

Posts.Content: May 30, 2012 02:56AM Fergy wrote: Wilson33, They are not going to give you results from this thermography until they do a comparison in 90 days?  That doesn't sound right.  They should give you this one and then compare and give you another report in 90 days.  hmmm! Anyway, I went to my new PCP and he felt the lump in my right breast too.  He said it feels like a cyst to him but he ordered a Digital Diagnostic mammogram anyway just to be sure.  He found another lump in my left breast that he said felt the same so he believes they are cysts.  I didn't think menopausal women get cyst in their breast but apparently we do.  I mentioned the thermography to him and he said that he doesn't believe in using them as a diagnostic tool because the results are not consistent enough.  I am not surprised at that response I must admit.  He did not order the ultrasound, said let's see what the mammogram says first.  URGH!  If the mammogram comes back OK, I am going to insist on an ultra sound anyway.  It really irritates me that we have to fight for our health! The goofy lump has not grown in 2 months but when I checked in the shower this morning it seemed bigger.  URGH! Good Luck and let me know what your thermography report says.  I am interested in real life experiences with this.  My report is just riddled with disclaimers which makes me suspicious.
Posts.Title: Itchy left nipple wilson33 Gingerbits

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2012 01:16PM Fergy wrote: I had a biopsy and had to sign a paper authorizing them to put the titanium clip in.  They did do a follow up mammogram to make sure the placement was correct right after the biopsy. My breast surgeon had scheduled an appointment 1 week after the biopsy to discuss the results.  I waited anxiously in her waiting room for 1 1/2 hours after my appointment, then I told the nurse to just give me the results so I could leave.  Then they put me in a room where I sat for another 1/2 listening to the BS in the next room talking to a patient telling a story about how much trouble she had ordering a replacement credit card????  By the time she got to me I was so irritated I didn't even want to speak to her.  My results were sclerosing adenosis and I had a bunch of questions but didn't want to speak to her.  I took the results to another BS, whom I loved, and asked him all the questions I needed.   Then I contacted my insurance company and disputed any office charges the BS billed them for giving me the results and refused to pay my co-payment.  Never heard back from her after that.  Once I received the copy of the report from the receptionist I noticed it had been faxed to the BS on Friday, she made me wait until my appointment on Wednesday for the results!!! Find another BS.  I think sometimes when they see B9 results they put it off as not important.  Well the results are important to us!!!
Posts.Title: Biopsy follow-up questions maiyen Fergy

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2010 10:16AM - edited Apr 11, 2010 10:17AM by Fergy I had a mammogram rated BIRADS 4C in March 2009.  My PCP called and told me that I had to see a surgeon in order to get the biopsy.  I had to wait one week to get in to see her and then had to wait another week to get the biopsy done.  The breast surgeon told me to make an appointment for one week after the biopsy to discuss the results.  She had the results on Friday, which were B9, but made me wait until my appointment on Wednesday to give me the results.  If I could have just went right to biopsy and skipped the surgeon all together I would have done that definitely. The breast surgeon also suggested after giving me the B9 results of the stereotactic biopsy that I let her do an excisional biopsy to be sure.  I declined and took my results to another surgeon for a secon opinion.  He suggested a 6 month follow up mammorgram which showed everything was stable. I think seeing a surgeon before biopsy is a waste of time and money!  If I ever get in that situation again I will not do it.
Posts.Title: Need your opinions... annyo snowiecal

I had a BIRADS 4C Mammogram 3 years ago that prompted a stereotactic biopsy which resulted in a B9 result. Best of luck to you.
Posts.Title: MRI baseline of BIRAD2 now a year later BIRAD 4B Southbay22 Southbay22

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2009 11:49PM Fergy wrote: Hello Ladies, I was on another board several months ago regarding calcifications.  I had a mammo the first of March that came back BIRADS 4C.  I had a stereotactic biopsy done March 25th.  The results were inconclusive so I opted for the six months wait and see program.  I didn't care for my breast surgeon so I got a second opinion.  I found great comfort in conversing with the ladies on these discussion boards while I was going through my testing period.  I don't always comment but I jump on every now and then to see how everyone is doing.  My six months is coming up in a couple of weeks so I have to call the doctor tomorrow and get the orders for my follow up mammogram. The reason I am writing is because I received conflicting information from the medical personal when I was going through testing etc. and was pretty sure that I had some type of cancer because of my BIRADS 4C results with pleomorphic microcalcification clusters and the reaction that my doctor had to it.  They got a really good sample of my calcifications and my new surgeon said he believed they got most of them. I am confident that my follow up mammogram will show no changes and no need for another biopsy.  I feel that I wasted too much time preparing myself for a negative outcome and then felt guilty when I got a benign result and another lady on the discussion board received a cancer diagnosis.  My suggestion is to stay positive and don't prepare for a negative result until you actually have results.  As hard as it is to do, don't let your mind wander to dark places while waiting for test results.  Most of the time the results are B9.  I hope this helps.
Posts.Title: Pleomorphic Calcifications mommyalways Isellrejer

Posts.Content: May 21, 2012 10:15PM Fergy wrote: pamelahope, that was very inpirational.  Than you for sharing!  And good luck to you with your results.
Posts.Title: Feeling better - what helped pamelahope pamelahope

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2009 05:23PM Fergy wrote: dragonfly628, I had a mammogram done Sep 2008 which showed a calcification cluster and was orderd to do a follow up mammo in 6 months.  I went in March 2009 and had punctuate and amorphous calcifications too.  The radiologist recommended a stereotactic biopsy, which I had done and the results were benign.  I now have to follow up with 6 month mammograms with my breast surgeon until he is comfortable that I am OK.  It is my understanding that when they see calcification clusters and vascular calcifications they suspect DCIS, IDC or LCIS.  I was told that calcifications are a result of rapid changing cells, which is what cancer cells do.  80% of the time they are benign but 20% of the time they are cancer so a biopsy is usually suggested.  Did your radiologist recommend a biopsy? My last mammogram was a BIRADS 4C rating, did they tell you what yours is?  I got my report from the radiologist and read it myself.  If you have a biopsy it is recommened that you get a copy of your pathology report too.  I had one surgeon tell me everything was negative.  I didn't feel comfortable with her and got a second opinion only to find out that I have a pre-cancerous condition.  That doesn't mean that I will get cancer it just puts me in a higher risk category but it is different from "negative, negative, negative" like the first surgeon told me. There are a lot of women on this website that have been diagnosed and who frequently monitor these boards.  I am sure one will jump on soon and give you more detailed information.  They are very knowlegable and I personally found this discussion board a great source of information and comfort while going through my diagnosis.  Most of the women that were posting at the same time I was got benign results so I think the 80% benign fact is pretty acurate.  What I learned from this discussion board is don't panic and don't get too convinced of the outcome until you actually get a pathology report after a biopsy.  I wanted to be prepared for a cancer diagnosis and I know now that you don't need to be.  If you have a biopsy done and you get a cancer diagnosis you have time to digest everything and do your research before making a decision on treatment.  Radiologist recently started using digital mammography versus analog mammography so they are able to see more calcifications than they used to.  All studies show that there are more biopsies being performed due to calcification detection today than ever before because of the digital mammography.  Just take one test and one step at a time and try not to panic. Fergy
Posts.Title: Mammogram dragonfly628 dragonfly628

Posts.Content: May 1, 2012 09:08PM Fergy wrote: I had a biopsy done on my thyroid by the endrocrinologist in his office a few years ago.  He looked at the slides before coming back in to see me and said "We won't know for sure until we get the pathology report back, but what I saw did not look like anything malignant".  The pathology report came back as B9. I think they do have a pretty good idea when they look at cells but only a pathologists knows for sure.  I agree that it is a good sign that it isn't an obvious malignancy. Good Luck to you.
Posts.Title: Waiting, scared, confused dankay2 marie5890

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2009 10:24AM - edited Aug 31, 2009 11:34AM by Fergy It doesn't matter how ridiculous something seems to us it is real emotion to others.  The purpose of these boards is to be able to express ourselves without being ridiculed. Fergy There are two situations that I was referring to in my previous post.  One was a woman that knew in her gut that something was wrong and got a B9 result.  She was correct and later she was diagnosed with IDC.  The second one has had so many biopsies that her breast are scared and out of shape now.  She wishes they would just find an early stage of cancer so they can take care of it and she won't have to keep going through the agony of biopsy and wait like she has for several years.  Hopefully this elaboration makes my previous comment not seem so "ridiculous".

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2012 11:17AM Fergy wrote: Every time I have had a doctor tell me the cells looked B9 they were B9.  So that is a good sign that the surgeon said they look B9.  However, only a pathologist looking at the cells will say for sure what it is.  There are some B9 conditions that put you at higher risk. I would rest a little easy knowing it is not an obvious cancer but still wouldn't give the big sigh until Friday.
Posts.Title: Had Biopsy Thursday LisaDVM Dmpalmer

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2009 09:51AM Fergy wrote: Clarice, Don't get too prepared for a carcinoma diagnosis since they really don't know for sure until the pathology report comes back.  Keep the faith, there is always hope.  I have heard of some women getting so prepared for a cancer diagnosis that they were actually disappointed when their results came back B9 and had a hard time adjusting to it. Like Leaf says on some of the other boards.  Just take one test at a time and then prepare for whatever the results are. Fergy

I can so relate to what you are saying about the fine line between intuition and paranoia.  I often wonder that myself.  So I just pray that if there is a problem and the medical field can't find it then I will have some other outward sign that will be undeniable.  Then you go on and live you life.
Posts.Title: Confused about my upcoming BS appointment pp729 Sommer43

Posts.Content: May 21, 2012 07:59PM Fergy wrote: Well said Sommer43!  I did the same thing as Rose NJ the first time around.  I had many call backs for mammograms but went years without a biopsy.  Then in spring of 2009 I had my mammogram and got a call from the PCP saying I was BIRAD 4C and go straight to a breast surgeon.  I Googled till my fingers bled.    Only to find out that my stereotactic biopsy showed Sclerosing Adenosis, a B9 breast condition. Now I think to myself, plane crashes happen with greater frequency than BC diagnosis do but I think nothing about getting on a plane and flying half way around the world for vacation.  So I need to have the same attitude with mammograms, ultra sound and biopsies.  From now on I assume that they will be B9 or follow up in one year and live my life.  Like I said before, if I do get a diagnosis of BC then I know where to go for advice from experienced survivors....www.breastcancer.org!
Posts.Title: 1st biopsy failed now going for a 2nd one on Wednesday Rose_NJ Blessings2011

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2009 10:44AM Fergy wrote: rdcalifornia, I had a BIRADS 4C mammogram in March followed by a stereotactic biopsy that was B9.  I didn't like my surgeon so I went to a second opinion surgeon who was wonderful.  He explained that the results were B9 but said I have a precancerous condition and ordered a follow up mammogram in 6 months.  I had my f/u mammo last week which the technician told me I have new calcifications.  I meet with the surgeon Friday 9/11 (Geez I just realized the date ) to review the films and get another breast exam.  In March my instincts told me it was malignant but I now think it was because of the reaction that my GP had to the BIRADS 4C rating.  I had a mammo done Sept 08 that was BIRADS 3 for multiple calcifications.  This time I am not so worried since I know the odds are in my favor.   Marlegal is correct that most people with B9 results don't post after getting their results.  I keep coming back to read these boards because I was desperately looking for someone with a BIRADS 4C rating that got B9 results last March and I want to be there for people that were in my position.  There were actually several that had B9 results and one woman told me she has even seen BIRADS 5 women get B9 results.  Don't lose hope. Hope this helps!
Posts.Title: 4th test in 2 weeks coming up rdcalifornia Fergy

Posts.Content: May 11, 2012 11:12AM Fergy wrote: That was my experience too.  I got a call from my PCP saying my mammogram was a BIRADS 4C and he wanted me to see a BS.  The BS will decide which is the best biopsy to have, there are several types, and then order it with the radiologist.  I don't believe the radioligist can determine which type of biopsy is needed, they just perform the proceedures ordered by the surgeons. I had a stereotactic biopsy that came back B9.  Because I have "busy breasts" the BS still wanted to do an excisional biopsy but I decided to take the wait and watch approach.  That was 3 years ago.  I have had clear mammograms ever since.  Recently I found a small lump in the same breast that I am watching until my annual mammogram in July.  I wish I had done the excisional when it was suggested and will if it is suggested this time.
Posts.Title: Confused about my upcoming BS appointment pp729 Sommer43

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2009 12:37PM Fergy wrote: kat43, BIRADS stands for Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System.  It is the rating scale that radiologist use to rate a mammogram result.  If you google the word BIRADS you should get a link that tells you what the ratings mean.  The scale goes from 0 to 6.
Posts.Title: 4th test in 2 weeks coming up rdcalifornia Fergy
